title-group.article-title: The Costs and Benefits of Moral Suasion: Evidence from the Rescue of Long‐Term Capital Management*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This study examines the level of unsecured borrowing done by the firms that ultimately rescued Long‐Term Capital Management in the days leading up to the hedge fund’s rescue. Although these banks borrowed less at the height of the crisis, evidence suggests that this reduction in borrowing was demand‐driven and did not result from rationing by the market. Further, it is shown that large banks that were not involved with the LTCM rescue saw the rates they pay for unsecured funds decline following the hedge fund’s resolution. This finding is consistent with an increase in the strength of a too‐big‐to‐fail policy.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The events surrounding the downfall and ultimate rescue of the hedge fund Long‐Term Capital Management (LTCM) were portrayed as they were happening as a serious threat to the health of the U.S. economy. As is well known, the Federal Reserve played a key role in organizing and hosting meetings for the institutions that would ultimately recapitalize the hedge fund. In justifying Fed involvement in the resolution, Federal Reserve Bank of New York president William J. McDonough said that “the abrupt and disorderly closeout of Long‐Term Capital’s positions would pose unacceptable risks to the US economy” (McDonough1998, 1051). This quote emphasizes that much of what was driving the Fed’s involvement with LTCM was the uncertainty regarding the consequences of doing the alternative, namely, letting the fund collapse and having its financial contracts unwound in a forced liquidation. Because it was difficult to know what might have happened in the absence of Fed involvement, policy makers chose to facilitate a resolution that allowed the hedge fund’s financial contracts to be closed out in an orderly fashion. One important consequence of the Fed’s choice was that it avoided potentially excessive financial hardship or possibly the failure of major commercial and investment banks.

After the fact, it is difficult to determine whether or not the Fed’s decision to intervene was a good one because one can directly observe only the benefits of the action (orderly resolution and no major bank failures) but not the costs. Nevertheless, this paper attempts to provide some evidence on the magnitude of the benefits and costs of the Fed’s action. To do so, I will focus on a set of nine large commercial banks that belonged to the group of 14 institutions that jointly rescued LTCM. I will refer to these institutions as the “LTCM banks.” These banks’ willingness to participate in the rescue suggests that these were the institutions that would have experienced significant losses had LTCM not been resolved in an orderly manner.

To shed light on the magnitude of the benefits of Fed involvement, the paper will examine whether financial markets thought that the troubled hedge fund would cause the failure of or major distress to the LTCM banks. In particular, the paper will examine the level of unsecured overnight borrowing done by these nine institutions as an indication of whether the market believed that these banks had a significant risk of insolvency during September 1998. If markets believed that the solvency of these nine institutions was in doubt, then these institutions should have had trouble borrowing large quantities of unsecured funding overnight.1

To consider the potential costs of Fed involvement, I look for evidence that might suggest that the safety net was expanded by the Fed’s involvement with LTCM. For example, if the market interpreted Fed intervention as a strengthening of an implicit too‐big‐to‐fail (TBTF) policy, then one might expect large banks that were not LTCM banks to have been viewed as an implicitly safer counterparty after the resolution relative to before the crisis. The ability of such institutions to borrow at more favorable terms following the resolution of LTCM would be evidence in support of this notion. To address this question, I examine the rates paid by large banks that were not exposed to LTCM before and after the hedge fund’s resolution.

Analysis of data from the unsecured, overnight federal funds market delivers the following empirical results. First, the nine LTCM banks dramatically reduced their net borrowing (i.e., the difference between their borrowing and lending) of overnight, unsecured funds during the last days of the crisis period. However, it is shown that this reduction was driven by an increase in the gross level of overnight lending done by these same institutions and not by a decrease in gross borrowing. These findings suggest that the nine banks were voluntarily reducing their net borrowing of overnight funds rather than being rationed from the market. The lack of rationing, in turn, implies that market participants were not overly worried about the solvency of these institutions. Second, the paper finds that large and complex U.S. commercial banks that were not exposed to LTCM paid lower interest rates to borrow overnight, unsecured money after the hedge fund’s rescue than they did before the crisis began to unfold. One interpretation of this finding is that the market has viewed the Fed’s action as an enhancement of TBTF.

The paper is organized as follows.Section IIdiscusses the benefits and costs of the LTCM rescue.Section IIIbriefly reviews what the literature has concluded about the LTCM episode.Section IVdescribes the data used in the study.Section Vprovides the analysis of the federal funds market during 1998 and documents the main empirical results mentioned above.Section VIprovides some robustness of my findings by examining more limited data from stock and bond markets.Section VIIpresents conclusions.

fn.p: Implicitly, the empirical tests are a joint test of the market’s belief that LTCM would cause an LTCM bank to fail and that policy makers would allow this bank to fail. Too‐big‐to‐fail issues are discussed more fully inSec. VD .

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Benefits and Costs
sec.p: On September 23, 1998, it was announced that a consortium of 14 large financial institutions had come to the collective rescue of the hedge fund Long‐Term Capital Management. Further, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York facilitated this rescue through its provision of “good offices” (Greenspan1998, 1048). Barring such a rescue, it was feared that the forced liquidation of the heavily leveraged hedge fund would lead to large losses at many of the world’s largest commercial and investment banks and even cause significant losses at firms with no direct relationship to LTCM.

These large losses could have arisen in at least two distinct ways. First, financial institutions could lose money on their direct credit exposures to the ailing hedge fund, even if these exposures were supposedly “fully collateralized.” In particular, the Fed feared that losses at major financial institutions might cause a rush to liquidate collateral that could, in turn, lead to unpredictable and possibly severe price movements in the markets for collateral assets. As a result, collateral could become insufficient to cover credit losses both at the directly exposed institutions and also at a much broader set of financial institutions holding the same financial instruments.2Second, losses could arise from banks’ proprietary trading operations that were taking financial positions like those of LTCM. Thus when markets moved against LTCM, they simultaneously moved against the institutions that were following similar strategies.

In explaining the Fed’s role in testimony to Congress, Fed chair Alan Greenspan said that “there is no reason for central bank involvement unless there is a substantial probability that a fire sale would result in severe, widespread, and prolonged disruptions to financial market activity” (1998, 1047). Federal Reserve Bank of New York president William McDonough supported Greenspan’s position by arguing in similar congressional testimony: “there was a likelihood that a number of credit and interest rate markets would experience extreme price moves and possibly cease to function for a period of one or more days and maybe longer” (1998, 1052).

Other observers have portrayed the Fed’s role as the action of a risk‐averse central bank hoping to avoid unpredictable and potentially solvency‐threatening losses at major financial institutions. For instance, Edwards (1999, 204) argues as follows:
Perhaps the more honest case for Fed intervention in LTCM would not pretend that the Fed was merely an interested bystander, but would simply argue that it was the best way for regulators to intervene … had LTCM not been rescued, and had the solvency of banks and securities firms been threatened due to a fire sale liquidation of LTCM’s positions, then regulators would have to decide between relaxing capital standards [and] forcing the closure or re‐capitalization of some large institutions. Overall, then, the possible benefits of Fed intervention have at least two dimensions. First, such policy maker action would limit the market disruption arising from a forced liquidation of LTCM. Second, Fed intervention would prevent the failure of any major commercial or investment bank, thereby avoiding the disruptions to economic activity that such a failure might cause.

With regard to the costs of the Fed’s role in the LTCM resolution, some have argued that facilitating a private‐sector rescue of a failing hedge fund was TBTF in disguise. In other words, since the Fed’s action prevented major commercial and investment banks from having to pay the full costs of a market‐imposed failure of LTCM, the central bank may have set a damaging precedent that implicitly extends the safety net. With regard to this possibility, the Fed has consistently argued that the costs of its actions were not likely to be severe. McDonough emphasized to Congress that “no Federal Reserve official pressured anyone, and no promises were made. Not one penny of public money was spent or committed” (1998, 1053). Policy makers, however, did not claim that their actions could be taken without regard for the potential impact on the safety net. As Greenspan concluded, “we do not have the choice of accepting the benefits of the current system [of a wide safety net] without its costs” (1998, 1050).

Outside the Fed, there has been more criticism of the Fed’s action. According to Dunbar’s (2000) description of events, LTCM’s chief executive officer John Meriwether intentionally involved the Fed with the fund’s troubles to secure a better outcome for the firm. Meriwether had been a successful bond trader at Salomon Brothers when that firm underwent investigation for submitting false bids at Treasury bond auctions. At that time, the viability of Salomon came into question since the magnitude of the Fed’s punishment of the firm was uncertain. Describing how the Fed became involved with LTCM, Dunbar (2000, 218) writes, “But Meriwether also remembered how [1991 New York Fed president] Corrigan had relented on his punishment of Salomon [because of] … the spectre of ‘systemic risk’, and the dangers of allowing a major bankruptcy on Wall Street. Perhaps [1998 New York Fed president] McDonough … could be played in the same way.”

The previous discussion documents both the benefits and costs of Fed involvement in the LTCM rescue. In what follows, the market’s perception of one of the benefits, namely preventing the failure of major financial institutions, is examined. The conclusion reached, that the solvency of the LTCM banks was never in serious doubt, is in part already understood. In particular, months after the rescue, Fed governor Laurence Meyer reported to Congress on the Fed’s review of supervisory practices following the LTCM incident and stated that “our reviews indicated and the financial results indicate that, while the LTCM incident and other episodes over the past two years may have significantly impacted earnings, they did not threaten the solvency of any U.S. commercial banking institution” (1999, 317). What is novel about this paper, however, is that one can glean from the data what the market’s perception of the LTCM banks’ insolvency risk was at the time that the crisis was developing. Thus the findings could conceivably have been an input to any policy maker decision. Further, the finding that the LTCM resolution might have been interpreted as an extension of the safety net suggests that the Fed’s action may not have been costless, despite not directly involving any public money.

fn.p: Potentially exacerbating market conditions at the time was the concern that LTCM might file for bankruptcy in the Cayman Islands, suggesting that its creditors’ ability to liquidate their collateral may be in doubt.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Previous Studies
sec.p: With the exception of numerous press accounts and public statements by various Fed officials, there has been relatively little work related to the events surrounding the collapse of LTCM. In general, studies of this episode are hindered by the lack of publicly available information on the trading positions taken by LTCM and other institutions. Of the few academic analyses of the LTCM episode, Jorion (2000) and Scholes (2000) both discuss the lessons for modern risk management practices. Since Scholes was involved with LTCM, it is not surprising that he concludes that failures in the hedge fund’s sophisticated value‐at‐risk (VaR) models were not the cause of the fund’s demise. Rather, he believes the main lesson to be drawn is that policy makers and firms should rely more heavily on stress testing to ascertain vulnerabilities to potential crises. Jorion, while agreeing with Scholes that VaR approaches to risk management are not inherently flawed, does take issue with how the hedge fund applied this methodology. He shows that the method by which LTCM used VaR, namely optimizing portfolios subject to a VaR constraint, leads to potentially significant biases in the estimation of portfolio risk. Further, he stresses that LTCM made faulty assumptions with regard to portfolio correlations, arguing persuasively that many of LTCM’s supposedly uncorrelated positions were uniformly exposed to the risk of a generalized flight to liquidity. Thus the blame for LTCM’s demise lies not in the VaR methodology, but rather in its implementation.3

With regard to the potential costs of Fed intervention, Edwards (1999, 204), in a qualitative discussion of the LTCM crisis, argues that the Fed’s intervention in the LTCM episode will “probably not” expand the safety net. He further provides a useful background to the LTCM episode by documenting the growing significance of hedge funds and the events that led to LTCM’s demise. Edwards also notes that the Fed could have used traditional lender of last resort facilities to address the hedge fund’s problems rather than provide “good offices.”

Of particular relevance to this paper is a recent study by Kho, Lee, and Stulz (2000). These authors document an economically large and statistically significant decline in the equity price of the firms that would ultimately participate in the bailout of LTCM on or about September 2, when it first became public that LTCM had suffered very large losses in the month of August. Such a decline in equity prices did not occur in large banks that did not ultimately participate in the LTCM rescue. This result leads the authors to conclude that “the market was perfectly capable of distinguishing between banks that were at risk and those that were not three weeks before the rescue” (Kho et al.2000, 7). Thus their evidence runs counter to the claim that it was nearly impossible to know exactly who would be most affected by a forced liquidation if one were to have occurred. Further, Kho et al. document that the equity prices of these same firms fell again on September 24, the day after the hedge fund’s rescue was announced, suggesting that although the affected institutions may have been known before the resolution, themagnitudeof the losses may have not been.

fn.p: In contrast to these studies on the use of risk management by LTCM, Bank for International Settlements (1999a) emphasizes the lack of proper risk management on the part of the banks that had relationships with LTCM.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: The Role of the Federal Funds Market and Data Construction
sec.p: In this paper, I use data on the unsecured federal funds market. Before I explain how the data were constructed, it is useful to explain the general role of overnight money markets in the day‐to‐day management of financial institutions. Banks use overnight money markets as their marginal source and use of funds. For instance, a bank that has excess funds may find it beneficial to lend to another institution overnight. This lending can be done against collateral, in which case this transaction is deemed a reverse repurchase (repo) agreement. Alternatively, the loan can be unsecured. Depending on the method by which the money is transferred, this loan of unsecured overnight money may be a federal funds transaction. Conversely, a bank may find itself short of funds one day. Such a bank might therefore increase its overnight borrowing, and, again, the most common approaches would be to enter into a repo transaction or to borrow unsecured.

Nearly all unsecured overnight borrowing between U.S. commercial banks is settled (i.e., the money is delivered) using Fedwire, the large‐value transfer system owned and operated by the Federal Reserve, and thus these loans have become known as federal funds transactions.4These unsecured loans form the basis of the analysis conducted inSection V. To identify individual transactions, data on every payment transferred across Fedwire during 1998 were collected.5Each payment identifies, among other items, the sending and the receiving bank and the amount, in dollars and cents. Stigum (1990) states that federal funds transactions are typically in round lots and are at least $1 million in value. Therefore, Fedwire payments that were at least $1 million and ended in five zeros (seven including cents) were identified as candidates for federal funds being delivered. Then, for each of these possible deliveries, the following day’s payments were searched for a payment between the same two banks in the opposite direction in an amount that could reasonably be construed as the initial payment plus interest. Interest rates were restricted to range between 50 basis points below the minimum and 50 basis points above the maximum rates witnessed by the federal funds brokers surveyed each day by the Fed.

Pairs of payments on adjoining business days satisfying these search criteria were identified as a federal funds transaction. For example, if the Fedwire transaction data contain a payment from bank A to bank B for $10 million on Tuesday and also a payment from bank B to bank A for $10,001,527.78 on Wednesday, then this was identified as a federal funds loan of $10 million from bank A to bank B on Tuesday at an interest rate of 5.50%.6This process identified 781,675 transactions over the 252 business days.7On the basis of the information contained in the underlying Fedwire payments, each transaction identifies the borrowing bank, the lending bank, the amount of the loan, and (implicitly) the interest rate charged.

Twenty‐five basis points may be a reasonable estimate of how much a bank could reasonably be expected to pay relative to its peers before being rationed from the market. For instance, during the height of the fears regarding Continental Illinois, Ellis and Flannery (1992) note that Continental failed to report offering rates for its uninsured certificates of deposit between May 16 and October 3, 1984, signaling that no interest rate would compensate potential lenders for the nontrivial risk of default. In the two weeks immediately prior to its absence from this market, the rates offered by Continental Illinois were, on average, 25.9 basis points above the average rate offered by other large banks. Whether the threshold of adverse signaling occurs at 25 basis points or at some other level, it is clear that if the market perceives a bank’s overnight default probability to be sufficiently large, quantity rationing should be expected. Thus, if one is interested in the market’s perception of the solvency of the LTCM banks in the days leading up to the LTCM rescue, it is appropriate to look for evidence of rationing rather than changes to the interest rates that these institutions were paying. By contrast, when examining the aftermath of the LTCM episode to examine whether there was an increase in the strength of a TBTF policy, one is interested to know whether the markets believed that a small decrease had occurred in certain banks’ probability of default. Thus it is appropriate to focus on the interest rates paid by institutions potentially made better off by the resolution.

fn.p: Respondents may also lend money unsecured and overnight to their correspondent bank, but these transactions are processed as accounting entries on the books of the banks and therefore do not involve Fedwire.

The Fedwire system distinguishes between payments made on the “funds” system and those made on the “book entry” system. The funds system tracks payments that are not contingent on any other payment. This system will include both the delivery and the repayment of federal funds transactions. The book entry system records payments made at the same time that a security is being delivered. Thus the book entry system would track the funds transfer end of repurchase agreements on securities eligible for Fedwire settlement. The data in this study come from Fedwire funds payments and therefore will not include the funding leg of a repo transaction.
Federal funds transactions are quoted on a discount yield basis.

By design, this search approach identifies only overnight transactions. However, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York (1987) survey, overnight transactions account for 96% of the funds market.
The daily effective funds rate is the volume‐weighted average of all funds traded in this market that were brokered by the set of firms surveyed each day by the Federal Reserve.

As the term suggests, these are not simply the 33 largest banks in the United States; the bank’s level of complexity is also considered. The smallest of the 33 LCBO banks is the forty‐sixth largest bank in terms of year‐end 1998 total assets.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Evidence from the Federal Funds Market

sec.label: A.
sec.title: The Empirical Model
sec.p:
The hypothesis to be tested in this section is whether participants in the federal funds market rationed the LTCM banks in the days leading up to the hedge fund’s rescue. Implicitly, I make the same assumption made by Kho et al. (2000), who assume that the 14 institutions that later agreed to rescue the hedge fund were known to the market in advance.10Of the 14, however, four (Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, and Morgan Stanley) are investment banks. As such, these institutions do not have accounts at a Federal Reserve bank, and therefore the overnight funding of these institutions is not included in the data constructed. Of the remaining 10 institutions, only nine participate directly in the overnight federal funds market and can be identified in the data.Table 1lists these 14 institutions and indicates the nine more closely examined in this study. I focus initially on a bank’s level of net borrowing. That is, the dependent variable will be a measure of the difference between a bank’s borrowing and lending of overnight funds on a given day. I do this because major federal funds market borrowers, among them the LTCM banks, are also the largest lenders. In other words, these banks not only use federal funds as their own marginal source and use of overnight money, they also serve as dealers in the market, both buying funds from and selling funds to smaller bank counterparties. Presumably, banks are ultimately interested in targeting a given level of net borrowing, for it is net borrowing that measures a bank’s true economic level of overnight unsecured borrowing that can be used to fund investment activities.

To detect differences between borrowing levels immediately before the resolution and those during normal periods, it was required to limit the sample to institutions with enough presence in the funds market to construe what “normal” levels were. With the first six months of 1998 defined as the “normal” period, the sample was trimmed to include only active market participants, chosen as those institutions that borrowed funds at least three out of every four days during the 126 business days of the first half of 1998. This selection criterion identified 164 institutions, including all nine LTCM banks. The full sample is listed intable 2.11

The variable subperiod tj is an indicator variable that equals one if datetis in subperiodj. The sample period of 1998 was divided into seven subperiods. The subperiods were chosen in an attempt to control for other events occurring during the same approximate time period.12In particular, the first subperiod was defined to include data from January 1 to June 30 and will be considered as the benchmark period. All the analysis will assume that observations from this part of the year accurately reflect the norm. Subperiods 2–6 are various nonoverlapping subperiods of 1998 beginning on July 1 and continuing until December 31. More precisely, the second subperiod was chosen to run from July 1 to August 16 and therefore covers the period just before the announcement that Russia would default on its government debt. The third subperiod stretches from the Russian debt announcement to September 1, the day before it became public that LTCM had suffered tremendous losses for the month of August. The fourth subperiod extends from the public awareness of LTCM troubles until September 17, the day before it became known in the market that the Federal Reserve was directly involved with the troubles surrounding the hedge fund. The fifth subperiod goes from September 18, the day the Fed became involved, until September 23, the day the rescue was announced (after the market closed). This subperiod is considered separately to control for the possibility that knowledge of Fed involvement might have conveyed new information to the market. The sixth subperiod, from September 24 until the end of 1998, represents the “aftermath.” The seventh subperiod directly addresses the findings of Kho et al. (2000). In particular, subperiod 7 contains the four days on which LTCM‐related banks suffered large equity price declines, specifically September 1, 2, 3, and 24.13

The variables of primary interest are the subperiod dummy variables interacted with the variable LTCM, which is defined to equal one whenever the borrowing bank is one of the nine LTCM banks and zero otherwise. The regressions also included four control variables in order to isolate the impact of being an LTCM bank. The first control is the variable Size, which was defined as the log of the borrowing bank’s worldwide total assets as of December 1998. Since all the LTCM banks are large, it is important to control for bank size to distinguish between effects common to the LTCM banks and those common to all very large institutions. Analogous to wanting to control for bank size, one might also wish to control for bank complexity. I measure complexity using the variable LCBO, which was defined to equal one if the borrowing bank was one of the 33 commercial banks identified as a large, complex banking organization.14

Another variable attempts to control for another major event that occurred at approximately the same time, specifically the default on Russian bonds. According to the Bank for International Settlements (1999c), the banks most heavily exposed to Russia during the latter part of 1998 were those in Germany. As bank level exposures to Russia were not available for the sample of 164 institutions, the paper attempts to control for the possible impact of the Russian default both by using various subperiods and by including a control variable Germany, which is equal to one if the particular institution was headquartered in Germany. Five of the 164 institutions in the sample were headquartered in Germany.

A final variable controls for the possibility that the nine LTCM banks may be more or less risky than the typical federal funds borrower. That is, banks might have refrained from lending to the LTCM banks during the crisis period not because they were particularly exposed to the troubles at LTCM, but because uncertain periods lead to a retrenchment away from riskier borrowers in general. The risk of an institution in this market can be proxied by the rates paid by a bank for overnight funds relative to what the market was paying. To be precise, interest rate spreads for each bank on each day were calculated as the difference between a bank’s actual volume‐weighted average rate paid for funds and that day’s effective federal funds rate. The average of this daily interest rate spread for each institution during the baseline period of January–June 1998 was defined as the control variable Risk (plotted infig. 1).

The estimated coefficients on the control variables also indicate that German banks had relatively high levels of net borrowing in early September but had no statistically significant change to their net borrowing immediately preceding LTCM’s resolution. The dummy variable for complex banks does not enter significantly before the resolution. Finally, the negative coefficients on the risk variable indicate that riskier institutions tended to borrow less during the second half of 1998, consistent with a flight from risk in this market.

The results reported in column 1 oftable 4for the nine LTCM banks document that after one controls for size and complexity, the LTCM banks had lower levels of net borrowing in the two‐month period before the hedge fund’s rescue. One possible explanation of this finding is that participants in the overnight money market believed that the LTCM banks had a serious chance of default. As a result, the market’s willingness to supply funds to these banks fell, causing them to be unable to maintain their net borrowing levels. Alternatively, the finding that the LTCM banks had lower levels of net borrowing might indicate that these institutions had a relatively lower demand for funds.

The ability to observe a bank’s gross borrowing and gross lending helps one to distinguish whether the lower level of net borrowing done by the LTCM banks was the result of market rationing (e.g., supply‐induced) or was intentional (e.g., demand‐induced). Columns 2 and 3 oftable 4report the results from analogous regressions, only replacing the dependent variable with the modifiedz‐score of the gross level of borrowing and the gross level of lending, respectively. For subperiod 3, the decline in net borrowing by the LTCM banks was driven by a decline in gross borrowing. If rationing caused this decline in gross borrowing, however, one would expect to find these banks decreasing their gross lending in an effort to maintain their net funding position. The results indicate, however, that during this period, the LTCM banks had no statistically significant change to their lending levels, and the point estimate is actually positive. I fail to find significant changes to gross borrowing or gross lending during subperiod 4, and the zero point estimate on gross borrowing and the positive point estimate on gross lending are again hard to reconcile with the notion of rationing. Particularly striking are the findings for subperiod 5. In the days immediately before the resolution, the large decline in net borrowing of the LTCM banks was being driven by a large and statistically significant increase in gross lending, suggesting very strongly that rationing was not responsible for the observed decline in net borrowing by the LTCM banks.

Further support for the conclusion that the LTCM banks were not being rationed comes from columns 4 and 5 oftable 4. These columns report the results from the same regression analysis, with the average interest rate paid for funds borrowed and the average interest rate received for funds lent relative to the effective rate used as the dependent variable, respectively.16In the final days before the resolution, there was no change in the interest rate paid by the LTCM banks for borrowed funds but a 5.011–basis point reduction in the average rate received for funds lent by these same institutions. These findings are consistent with the notion that the LTCM banks wanted to increase their interbank lending during this time period and were willing to sacrifice over five basis points to do so.

fn.p: Note that since the dependent variables in cols. 1–3 represent differences from the norm, γ1, β1, and φ q1∀qwill equal zero by construction because subperiod 1 is defined to be the norm.

In col. 4, the dependent variable is the rate paid for funds relative to the market. Thus the average value of the dependent variable during subperiod 1 is precisely equal to the variable Risk. As a result, the subperiod 1 coefficients are all zero except for the subperiod 1 coefficient on Risk, which is identically equal to one. In col. 5, the dependent variable relates to interest rates received and thus has no mathematical relationship to any of the independent variables.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Evidence from after the Resolution
sec.p: In this subsection, I provide evidence on whether the federal funds market’s willingness to lend to LTCM banks or other institutions changed after the hedge fund’s rescue. As such changes in willingness should be reflected in risk premiums, I look first at interest rates paid.Table 4also reports the estimates from subperiod 6, which reflects the time after the resolution was announced.17Column 4 indicates that after I control for bank size, LTCM banks saw the rates that they pay on overnight funds increase by 3.953 basis points, whereas LCBOs borrowed funds at an average rate 4.258 basis points lower after the LTCM resolution relative to the first half of 1998.

Changes to the rates paid by the LTCM banks relative to the market could be driven by two possibilities. First, the LTCM banks could have increased the amount they were borrowing and therefore driven up the rate they needed to pay. Second, the interbank market could have increased the rate that it requires in order to lend any given amount to the LTCM banks. That is, it is necessary to determine whether the higher interest rates paid for funds by the LTCM banks were a result of different market treatment (i.e. supply‐induced) or a result of a change in the behavior of the LTCM banks themselves (i.e., demand‐induced). The results in columns 1–3 oftable 4indicate that the LTCM banks reduced their borrowing and increased their lending relative to the baseline period. The resulting decline in net borrowing was even greater than what was documented for the days before the resolution. That lower borrowing levels were accompanied by higher interest rates suggests that the market was less willing to supply funds to these institutions. By contrast, the large, complex banking organizations were increasing their gross borrowing during this period yet paying a lower rate of interest. This suggests that the market became more willing to extend funds to these institutions.

fn.p: The results that follow are robust to the beginning of the “postcrisis” period after the Fed’s intermeeting cut on October 15.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Too Big to Fail
sec.p: The evidence presented in subsectionsBandCcan be summarized by the following two results. First, the LTCM banks were not rationed in the overnight funds market prior to the hedge fund’s resolution. Second, banks became less willing to lend to LTCM banks and more willing to lend to LCBO banks after the resolution. In this subsection, I explore to what extent a belief of TBTF can help explain these findings.

sec.title: The Market’s Assessment of TBTF before the Resolution
sec.p: Consider first the finding that LTCM banks were not rationed because the market believed that these major institutions were too big to fail. O’Hara and Shaw (1990) document that when the comptroller of the currency followed the bailout of Continental Illinois with an announcement that a set of institutions was TBTF, the stock prices of the affected institutions increased. This suggests that financial markets incorporate expectations of government guarantees. In the context of the current study, if market participants believed that the LTCM banks were completely TBTF (e.g., that there was a 100% guarantee that federal funds loans would be repaid in full), then there would be no need to ration credit to the LTCM banks, regardless of their probability of default. A 100% guarantee of repayment, however, is not consistent with the evidence presented infigure 1, which illustrates that the LTCM banks were not paying the lowest prices in the market for borrowed funds. Thus it may be more appropriate to consider the strength of a TBTF policy as an expected probability that such a guarantee would be made ex post.

Table 5explores how expectations of a TBTF guarantee might affect the federal funds market. The table reports the increase in the interest rate premium that a risk‐neutral lender would require to compensate itself for an increase in overnight default risk of various magnitudes as a function of the probability that the borrower is TBTF. For illustration, the figures in columns 3–8 assume a 100% loss in the event of the failure of its counterparty. For example,table 5indicates that a bank whose overnight default probability has increased by one in 100,000 will see its risk premium rise by 36 basis points for unsecured borrowing if it has no chance of being considered TBTF. The increase in the required risk premium is also 36 basis points when the borrower’s failure probability increases by one in 50,000 if there is a 50% chance that the borrower will be deemed TBTF. Thus, from the perspective of a lending institution, higher overnight default probabilities of a borrower are directly offset by higher probabilities of the borrower being considered TBTF. Clearly, if a borrowing institution is definitely TBTF, then there would be no need for a risk premium, much less any rationing. Table 5

Columns 9–11 oftable 5indicate the required likelihood of a TBTF rescue that is implicit in a bank’s continued willingness to lend money for various increases in overnight default probability. The columns differ with respect to the assumptions regarding how much risk premiums can increase before rationing sets in and the loss to the federal funds lender in the event of the failure of its counterparty. As argued earlier, it may be reasonable to assume that the LTCM banks would not pay more than an additional 25 basis points for fear of conveying to the market that something out of the ordinary was happening. With this assumption and a 100% loss given default, a lender would have to be more than 86% sure that the borrower is TBTF before being willing to lend if the overnight probability of default increases by one chance in 20,000. The results in column 11 oftable 5indicate that even if risk premiums could rise by 50 basis points and a federal funds lender would lose only 50% of its principal in the event of counterparty failure, lenders would still need to be over 72% confident of a TBTF rescue in order to continue to lend to an institution that suffers an increase in overnight failure probability of one in 10,000. Thustable 5indicates that even under fairly conservative assumptions, lenders would have needed to be reasonably sure that the LTCM banks were TBTF to be willing to continue to extend funds, even if these banks’ overnight default probability had risen by only one chance in 10,000.

Deciding whether markets should have reasonably expected such a high probability of a TBTF rescue is difficult given that there have been no major bank failures in the United States since the passage of the FDIC Improvement Act (FDICIA) in 1991. As Wall (1993) describes, FDICIA requires policy makers to resolve a failing organization according to the least costly method of resolution. By definition, this would preclude the complete protection of unsecured interbank creditors. Nevertheless, Wall describes FDICIA’s “systemic risk exception” clause, which allows unsecured creditors of a failing institution to be protected if failure to do so would “have serious adverse effects on economic conditions or financial stability” (p. 1). Although this clause in FDICIA does allow some potential for TBTF to survive, it seems reasonable to suggest that markets should have been far from certain that such a policy would have been applied to the institutions lending federal funds to the LTCM banks. In support of this claim, Benston and Kaufman (1998) find that uninsured depositors at failing U.S. banks have been protected noticeably less since FDICIA. Further, they note that the Bank of England did not fully protect uninsured depositors following the collapse of both Bank of Credit and Commerce International and Barings, even though it had pursued a TBTF policy earlier. Given this likely uncertainty surrounding a TBTF rescue, the failure of rationing to materialize suggests that the interbank market believed that the risk that the LTCM banks would default remained small.

sec.title: The Market’s Assessment of TBTF after the Resolution
sec.p: Consider now the finding that banks became less willing to lend to LTCM banks and more willing to lend to (non‐LTCM) LCBO banksafterthe resolution. Some argue that the Fed’s role in the resolution of LTCM was to solve a coordination problem among a diverse group of institutions. Interpreted in this light, the Fed’s action can be viewed as an ex post improvement to bankruptcy procedures. However, interpreting the Fed’s action in this way suggests that not all institutions should expect to benefit from such improved bankruptcy procedures in the future. In particular, the Fed’s action might be seen as increasing the protection given to major financial institutions because these institutions are the most likely to later benefit from similar Fed action. In this way, selective intervention might be viewed as analogous to a more traditional TBTF policy.

To understand how changes in the market’s TBTF perceptions might affect the rates paid for federal funds, it is helpful to recall the intuition behindtable 5. That table demonstrated that the rate that banks pay for funds is affected by (a) the inherent credit risk (e.g., default probability) of the institution and (b) the market’s belief that the institution is TBTF. Our empirical finding was that after the resolution, LTCM banks saw the rate they must pay for unsecured money rise and non‐LTCM, but LCBO, banks saw their rates fall.

In the absence of TBTF, the only way to rationalize the observed changes in interest rates would be to say that the market revised upward its assessment of the risk of the LTCM banks and revised downward its assessment of the risk of non‐LTCM, but LCBO, banks. This is a possibility. Higher interest rate spreads paid by the LTCM banks after the resolution might reflect the fact that the market, having witnessed an extraordinary crisis resolution, realized that the proprietary trading strategies undertaken by the LTCM banks may impose greater losses (i.e., are riskier) than earlier believed. Although the findings of Kho et al. (2000) suggest that the market knew which banks were undertaking these strategies weeks ahead of the resolution, it is possible that the actual magnitude of the potential losses was initially underestimated. The financial terms of the resolution may have conveyed to the market a larger, yet more accurate, estimate of the losses that these institutions faced. This would be consistent with the additional equity market decline Kho et al. document on the first trading day after the resolution (September 24) as well as the upward revision to these banks’ cost of unsecured funds reported in subectionC. Analogously, it could be the case that the lower interest rates paid by non‐LTCM LCBO banks reflect the market’s belief that since these banks did not undertake these risky trading strategies (as inferred from their lack of exposure to the LTCM crisis), they are actually safer than earlier thought. Again, the magnitude of the “benefit” of not undertaking these risky trading strategies may have been realized only after the terms of the resolution were announced.

While the above explanation is certainly consistent with the empirical findings, an alternative explanation of our empirical results incorporates the assumption that some TBTF perception remains in the market. Suppose that the Fed’s involvement in the LTCM rescue was perceived as an extension of a TBTF policy. Presumably, all large banks should benefit in the sense that they should then have a lower cost of funds. In particular, the benefit of an enlarged TBTF policy should be expected to benefit both LTCM banks and LCBO banks. Thus a strengthening of TBTF can explain the decline in the cost of funds to the LCBO banks but is inconsistent with the increased cost of funds for LTCM banks. However, an extension of TBTF, combined with the market’s upward revision of the risk of proprietary trading strategies of the LTCM banks, would be consistent with our results. For example, our point estimates would be consistent with a TBTF benefit of four basis points and an eight–basis point penalty for risky proprietary trading strategies.

It seems reasonable to believe that the higher cost of funds for the LTCM banks after the resolution reflects the market’s new assessment of the risks of these banks’ proprietary trading activities. Whether or not the lower cost of funds for the non‐LTCM LCBO banks reflects a downward assessment of their inherent risks or an extension of a TBTF policy is less clear. In interpretation of our empirical results, however, it is important to recall that a widening of the difference between the spreads paid by the LTCM banks and LCBO banks of approximately eight basis points is quite substantial, given that these institutions had previously paid similar premiums.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Robustness of Findings: A Comparison to Other Markets
sec.p: The empirical evidence presented inSection Vsuggests that in the federal funds market, the LTCM banks were penalized after the resolution, but not before. This is somewhat contrary to what one might believe should be the case. In particular, we know from Kho et al. (2000) that the stock prices of LTCM banks fell dramatically weeks before the eventual resolution. With all else held constant, most capital structure models suggest that a decline in a firm’s equity price should increase the firm’s failure probability that should be reflected in higher bond yields. Thus one might have expected to find higher yields on the LTCM banks’ unsecured debtbeforethe resolution, a finding that is absent from the federal funds market data. As I have argued, however, one possible explanation of this finding is that the market knew what institutions were affected before the resolution but significantly underestimated the magnitude of the impact. That is, the decline in the LTCM banks’ market value prior to the resolution may not have significantly raised these banks’ default probability on overnight loans.

To explore whether this explanation is likely, I construct a more limited sample of stock and bond market data to address how other financial markets responded to the LTCM crisis. I retrieve daily bank stock market data from the Center for Research in Security Prices for the U.S. commercial banks that ultimately helped rescue LTCM: Bankers Trust, Citibank, Chase, and JPMorgan. I then calculate the average daily holding period return for an equally weighted portfolio of these four stocks and subtract the return on the S&P bank stock index. Nonetheless, the most striking result intable 6is the finding for subperiod 6, the time after the hedge fund’s resolution. Even though the LTCM bank stocks were not performing differently than the bank stock index, the LTCM banks’ bond yields increased by an average of 36.5 basis points. Thus, as in the findings for the federal funds market reported inSection V, the most significant bond market reaction occurred after the resolution.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper has provided two key empirical results regarding the events surrounding the resolution of the hedge fund Long‐Term Capital Management. First, participants in the federal funds market did not restrict their lending to nine banks that ultimately participated in the hedge fund’s rescue. The observed decrease in net borrowing done by these nine banks was accompanied by an increase in their interbank lending, suggesting that the decline in net borrowing was by choice. Numerical estimates suggest that a perception of too big to fail also seems unlikely to be the driving force behind this result. These findings suggest that the market never believed that these major institutions had a significant probability of default.

The second major result of the paper is the finding that large, complex banking organizations began paying lower interest rates for unsecured overnight money following the resolution of the LTCM crisis, whereas the LTCM banks began paying higher rates. It seems likely that the higher rates paid by LTCM banks reflect the market’s upward assessment of the risks of these banks’ proprietary trading operations. With regard to the lower rates paid by LCBO banks not exposed to the troubles at LTCM, one possibility is that markets viewed these banks as safer because they did not undertake such risky trading strategies. Alternatively, this result suggests that the Fed’s action, even though it provided no public money, may have been perceived in the market as an implicit extension of a TBTF policy.

Ultimately, these findings cannot lead one to conclude whether the Fed should have intervened in the way in which it did because the benefits and costs of Fed action are neither measured in their entirety nor weighted by an appropriate social welfare function. Nevertheless, the results suggest that the benefits of Fed intervention may have been lower and the costs higher than perceived at the time.
